text:
Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

In my opinion,

But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

College athletes are in many ways comparable to athletes older than them, that participate in professional leagues outside of colleges and universities. Many of college athletes put in tremendous amount of effort and their time to improve their abilities, and to seek achievement of the sport of their choosing. This effort and time is primarily reflected in the outcomes of the sport for the colleges they are associated with, whether it is the games they win for their teams, or the records they may break in other types of sports.

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

College athletes are in many ways comparable to athletes older than them, that participate in professional leagues outside of colleges and universities. Many of college athletes put in tremendous amount of effort and their time to improve their abilities, and to seek achievement of the sport of their choosing. This effort and time is primarily reflected in the outcomes of the sport for the colleges they are associated with, whether it is the games they win for their teams, or the records they may break in other types of sports. 

College athletes are also in many ways comparable to other students, who are not athletes. They still have educational obligations to meet apart from the demands of the sport, which in too can conflict with work demands if they hold one. Having to juggle a variety of obligations in a day can be tiring and stressful, which impacts the performance of a college athlete much like any other type of athlete. However, the college athletes that are not paid to the same degree as professional athletes like in the MLB, NFL, NHL, and much more will no doubt be subjected to much more stressors from the lack of finances.

The argument that college athletes should not be paid is based on the idea that the current system of scholarships and other benefits is enough.

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

College athletes are in many ways comparable to athletes older than them, that participate in professional leagues outside of colleges and universities. Many of college athletes put in tremendous amount of effort and their time to improve their abilities, and to seek achievement of the sport of their choosing. This effort and time is primarily reflected in the outcomes of the sport for the colleges they are associated with, whether it is the games they win for their teams, or the records they may break in other types of sports. 

College athletes are also in many ways comparable to other students, who are not athletes. They still have educational obligations to meet apart from the demands of the sport, which in too can conflict with work demands if they hold one. Having to juggle a variety of obligations in a day can be tiring and stressful, which impacts the performance of a college athlete much like any other type of athlete. However, the college athletes that are not paid to the same degree as professional athletes like in the MLB, NFL, NHL, and much more will no doubt be subjected to much more stressors from the lack of finances. 

The argument that college athletes should not be paid that is based on the idea that the current system of scholarships and other benefits is enough is a flawed line of thinking. That is assuming that college athletes like other students, don't accumulate debt through other expenses apart from the ones necessary to pay for their education. Scholarships and other benefits are sufficient to pay for tuition and the cost of materials, but like other students, many of college athletes have other areas to attend to. This includes living arrangements, food, hobbies, and much more than will be difficult to pay for with scholarships and other benefits, more so for some than others. College athletes often will struggle between their obligations to make money if they aren't being paid for their efforts in the sport, given that a part-time or even full-time job is difficult enough for students with educational demands.

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

College athletes are in many ways comparable to athletes older than them, that participate in professional leagues outside of colleges and universities. Many of college athletes put in tremendous amount of effort and their time to improve their abilities, and to seek achievement of the sport of their choosing. This effort and time is primarily reflected in the outcomes of the sport for the colleges they are associated with, whether it is the games they win for their teams, or the records they may break in other types of sports. 

College athletes are also in many ways comparable to other students, who are not athletes. They still have educational obligations to meet apart from the demands of the sport, which in too can conflict with work demands if they hold one. Having to juggle a variety of obligations in a day can be tiring and stressful, which impacts the performance of a college athlete much like any other type of athlete. However, the college athletes that are not paid to the same degree as professional athletes like in the MLB, NFL, NHL, and much more will no doubt be subjected to much more stressors from the lack of finances. 

The argument that college athletes should not be paid that is based on the idea that the current system of scholarships and other benefits is enough is a flawed line of thinking. That is assuming that college athletes like other students, don't accumulate debt through other expenses apart from the ones necessary to pay for their education. Scholarships and other benefits are sufficient to pay for tuition and the cost of materials, but like other students, many of college athletes have other areas to attend to. This includes living arrangements, food, hobbies, and much more than will be difficult to pay for with scholarships and other benefits, more so for some than others. College athletes often will struggle between their obligations to make money if they aren't being paid for their efforts in the sport, given that a part-time or even full-time job is difficult enough for students with educational demands. Paying them like other athletes will help them meet the demands of their finances as it relates to their education, personal life, and their sport.

The argument that paying college athletes would ruin the sport is also flawed, given that such a concept exist in professional leagues and other sports. Universities benefit much from college athletes, more so from the ones that have high prestige, performance, and reputation. The bidding wars and other excessive costs that universities pay for their athletes are in part of their own vocation, something that can be prevented through more regulation, and effecitvely the fair treatment of all college athletes for their efforts. These can be reduced so that the university will not impact other students, while still being able to pay athletes for their efforts that is necessary for them to continue their sports career, while also furthering their educational career.
